messageBody:
junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:

>> The approach I'd prefer would more look like
>>
>> Test1:
>> 1
>> Test2:
>> 1m-2
>> Test3:
>> 2m-3
>> Test4:
>> 3m-4
>
> That's better, and if we assume that the time to test mocks
> is negligible (a fair assumption), the execution time will indeed be
> acceptable.
>
> The problem is that you now find yourself writing a lot of code (all
> the mocks) just to emulate production code. I have a few problems
> with that:
>
> - Writing mocks takes time, especially for packages not
> designed for this (try mocking JMS factories or obscure JDBC
> drivers). It also forces you to maintain an entire parallel
> hierarchy and basically reimplement entire API's (which are
> sometimes based on concrete implementations and not
> interfaces). That's a lot of code clutter.

That's true. On the other hand it will also prevent a lot of trouble:

- it's easier to write the tests (which might already result in an
improvement in overall test writing time),
- the tests run faster,
- you can test conditions that are virtually impossible to reliably induce
without mocks,
- your overall design improves, because thinking about how to write the
mocks helps you to come up with better decoupled classes

In my experience, systematic use of mocks generally decreases development
time and improves code quality.

> But worse:
>
> - You are not testing exactly what goes in production.
> Introduce a subtle bug in your mock (return null instead of a
> real value) and your tests will pass on your test machines and fail
> in production.

True again. You will still want to have *some* integrations tests, that
fully test 1-2-3-4 in concert. In my experience it's more effective having
most of the tests not doing that, though.

> Writing mocks should be an option, but the testing framework
> should let me use dependencies and test production code if I
> so choose, and unfortunately, JUnit is of no help there.

You should keep in mind that Junit is meant to be a *unit* testing
framework, not a panacea. I'm quite comfortable with Junit concentrating on
its core responsibility, and using an extension or a different framework for
functional tests.

Take care, Ilja
